US MARKET WRAP: Stocks look through shutdown worries
content:
GOVERNMENT SHUTDOWN: Possibility of fresh House and Senate votes

As it stands, a gap remains between Republicans and Democrats in the Senate over DACA, putting an obstacle in the way of any deal to keep the government open.

Trump has met Democrat Minority Leader Schumer, and after the meeting, Schumer said some disagreements still remain; a White House official also confirmed that no deal has been reached. However, there were constructive comments from some other Democrat Senators (Brown, for instance).

The Rules Committee Chairman was quoted as saying that there could be another vote in the House tonight if Senate reach a deal that is different from the House’s version of the funding bill passed on Thursday.

 

EQUITIES: SPX +0.44% at 2810, DJI +0.21% at 26071, NDX +35% at 6834

Top performers:  Consumer Staples +1.11%, Consumer Discretionary 0.87%, Financials 0.68%

Bottom performers: Utilities -0.29%, Energy -0.10%,  IT +0.16%

The S&P 500 printed another fresh intraday record highs, looking through the threat of a government shutdown. Consumer sectors lead the gains on expectations of lower tax bills, as well as a solid global economic backdrop. On the other end of the scale, the defensive utilities sector was lagging, with energy also lower.

 

TREASURIES: 10-Year T-Note futures settle 5+ ticks lower at 122-09

The curve steepened on Friday, with yields on 2s c.2bps higher on the day, while the longer end was higher by c.3bps. However, major spreads narrowed again, with 2s10s marginally flatter, while 2s30s and 5s30s flattened by 0.5bps and 0.8bps at settlement, respectively. 2s5s, however, widened slightly.

The 10-year yield rose to just shy of 2.65%, and was getting some attention given that it is now within the “Gundlach zone”, which he said would put pressure on stocks.

Some had suggested that yields have been rising this week – in spite of little progress in passing a bill to keep the government open – on the back of rising commodity prices generating some upside inflation pressures. However, analysts have noted that such a driver has historically delivered little in terms of a sustainable, long-term impact on inflation.

 

FOREX: DXY red for the fifth straight week

The Dollar Index was flat on Friday, despite the looming threat of a government shutdown; the DXY finishes red for the fifth consecutive week, the longest loosing run since May 2015. And despite widening rate differentials between USTs and JGBs, the JPY continues to strengthened against the greenback.

The EUR was also flat on Friday, with the single currency eyeing Sunday’s vote in Germany to see if the SPD will enter into a government coalition. Analysts generally see EUR downside in the event that it votes against it, since it would raise the prospect of either another election in Germany, or a minority government.

Sterling was negative on the day after the strong gains made this week, finishing US trade shy of the 1.39 handle. With Brexit developments quiet, and a generally reasonable run of economic data, the pound found demand this week against the currencies weighed down by political uncertainty (USD, EUR).

 

COMMODITIES: WTI futures settle 58 cents lower $63.37 per barrel; Brent futures settle 70 cents lower at $68.61 per barrel

Oil prices slipped by the most this week since October, despite hitting a three-year high in the week.

The IEA reported on Friday that US crude output is expected to rise above 10mln BPD – in line with what OPEC reported on Thursday. It also said that global stockpiles were tightening substantially on the back of the OPEC/non-OPEC deal to curb output.  

Elsewhere, weekly rig count data showed US driller cutting active rigs for the second straight week.

- The Fed is not ahead of or behind the curve.

PREVIEW: SPD to vote on German coalition talks on Sunday
content:
As we are aware, Germany does not currently have a government. Nearly four months after the election, Chancellor Angela Merkel’s Christian Democratic Union (CDU) and sister Social Union (CSU) are desperately trying to form a stable government via a grand-coalition. This uncertainty is corroding Merkel’s public standing after 12 years as a dominant leader in the Eurozone where she now must count on the Social Democratic Party (SPD) and their leader Martin Schulz to once again agree to tie-up for the sake of a German government.

Six hundred SPD delegates are due to vote this Sunday regarding whether to embark on head-on coalition talks with CDU/CSU. Michael Groschek, the leader of the western state of North Rhine-Westphalia (NRW) which accounts for around a quarter of SPD delegates, joined Martin Schulz on a positive forecast for Sunday’s vote. SPD parliament leader Andrea Nahles stated about a third of delegates were still undecided however she was optimistic a majority of the party would vote to endorse the talks. On the other hand, she also conceded that SPD has not been fulfilled all its demands in the negotiations which include universal health care insurance, but added that other important projects are within reach. Building on this, SPD’s youth and left wings are opposing coalition talks stating that the blueprints do not contain enough SPD hallmarks.

Overall, expectations are mixed ahead of Sunday’s vote. A “yes” vote would spur detailed coalition negotiations between the two parties. Further delays in talks would seriously impact the EU as discussions regarding reforming its structures and financial priorities have been forced to be put on hold until a new government is in place in Berlin. Refusal by SPD delegates to hold further coalition talks could result in a new election that would likely be followed by even more painful coalition talks or the formation of the first post-war German minority government.

subject: FX Weekly Wrap: Dollar on tack to extend 2018 bear run
content:
DXY

The Usd continues its losing trend, albeit off worst levels for Friday’s session and the week as the Index reclaims 90.500 status, just. Still no evidence that higher US bond yields are providing the Greenback with any support, but the growing likelihood of a Government shutdown has not added to the Dollar’s woes either. Usd/G10 pairs are pretty mixed after some whippy trade, with Cable retreating from new post-Brexit vote highs (circa 1.3945) on much worse than expected UK retail sales data to test 1.3850 support, while Eur/Gbp took out stops around the 200DMA (0.8835) on the way to almost 0.8850. Eur/Usd rangy within 1.2230-95 parameters amidst more ECB sourced reports playing down Eur strength concerns and underlining new guidance prospects for March rather than next week’s January policy meeting. Revived NAFTA hopes on an extension to the latest discussions underpinned the Cad and Mxn, with the former back down towards 1.2400 vs the Usd having weakened earlier in the week on the ‘dovish’ BoC hike, while the Peso probed 2 month highs around 18.5400 (close to 200DMA support just below 18.5000). Usd/Jpy tested support at 110.50, but not a bigger downside chart level at 110.15 and the antipodeans retreated from best levels vs their US counterpart (Aud/Usd from 0.8040 towards 0.8000 and Nzd/Usd from 0.7325 back under 0.7300). Usd/Chf hovering around 0.9600 vs sub-0.9550 at one stage and now awaiting a White House statement on the possible (probable?) shutdown.

Fixed Income: choppy trade in bonds on multi-factors
content: A short squeeze in core debt futures amidst some volatile price action, initially on ECB sources claiming that the GC is not that fazed by Eur strength, but could extend QE by another 3 months from September, albeit no longer. Contacts also note RM buying in USTs, and mainly 10 year futures, following pre-US open selling at the short end and mid-curve. Meanwhile, reports suggest that there could well be a Government shutdown over the weekend and into next week, and the upshot is new session highs in fixed with Bunds up to 160.85 and Gilts to 123.82.

subject: DAILY US EQUITY OPENING NEWS -   General Mills (GIS) and Bed Bath and Beyond (BBBY) are both weighing investments in Boxed.com, according to sources. Sources also added Boxed.com is in advanced talks to be sold to Kroger (KR).
content:
19th January 2018

EARNINGS

American Express Co (AXP) - Q4 Adj. EPS USD 1.58 vs. Exp. USD 1.54, Revenue USD 8.84bln vs, Exp. USD 8.72bln, plans to suspend share buyback programme for first half of 2018 in order to rebuild capital. Further, it sees FY18 revenue growth between 7% and 8%. (Newswires)

Citizens Financial Group Inc (CFG) - Q4 EPS USD 0.71 vs. Exp. USD 0.67, Revenue USD 1.47bln vs, Exp. USD 1.45bln; boosts dividend to USD 0.22 from USD 0.18. (Newswires)

International Business Machines Corp (IBM) - Q4 Adj. EPS USD 5.18 vs. Exp. USD 5.16, Revenue USD 22.5bln vs, Exp. USD 22.05bln, Q4 cloud revenue up 30% to USD 5.5bln and it says due to the tax reform they incurred a USD 5.5bln charge in Q4 and note it is engaged in blockchain projects with hundreds of clients and forecasts FY18 EPS of at least USD 13.80, vs Exp. USD 13.92. (Newswires)

Kansas City Southern (KSU) – Q4 Adj. EPS USD 1.38, Vs Exp. USD 1.37, Revenue USD 660mln, vs Exp. 656.28mln. (Newswires)

Regions Financial Corp (RF) - Q4 EPS USD 0.27 vs. Exp. USD 0.26, revenue USD 1.49bln vs, Exp. USD 1.44bln. (Newswires)

Schlumberger NV (SLB) - Q4 Adj. EPS USD 0.48 vs. Exp. USD 0.44, revenue USD 8.20bln vs, Exp. USD 8.13bln. Further, it announces its plan to exit the marine and land seismic acquisition market. (Newswires)

SunTrust Banks Inc (STI) - Q4 EPS USD 1.48 vs. Exp. USD 1.05, Revenue USD 2.33bln vs, Exp. USD 2.31bln. (Newswires)

Synchrony Financial (SYF) - Q4 Adj. EPS USD 0.70 vs. Exp. USD 0.63. (Newswires)

 

DJIA

Apple (AAPL) – A S. Korean consumer group has filed a criminal complaint against CEO Tim Cook, the filing accuses him of destruction of property and fraud relating to the slowing down of older iPhones. Further, the tech giant will release a software update what will give users the ability to turn off a feature that slows down iPhones when batteries are low. Also, Samsung issued a statement saying it does not purposely slow down phones. Separately, Key Bank cut iPhone X estimates, and forecasts production end in 2018.  (Newswires)

Boeing (BA) – The plane maker is trying to overcome Brazilian military’s objection to the proposed tie-up with Embraer (ERJ) by looking at alternatives which would preserve the governments veto rights and ensure safeguards for its defence programmes. (Newswires)

IBM (IBM) / Salesforce (CRM) – The two companies announced the expansion of its strategic partnership. (Newswires)

Merck (MRK) – The pharmaceutical giant and AstraZeneca (AZN) announces Lynparza has received approval from the Japanese Ministry of Health, Merck also report its phase 2 Keynote-224 trial investigating Keytruda results showed an overall response rate of 16.3%.  (Newswires)

 

S&P 500

Bank of New York Mellon (BK) – The bank is to boost wages for 1000 workers after tax reform. (WSJ)

Berkshire Hathaway Inc (BRK.A) – Recently appointed vice chairman Ajit Jain reported an ownership of around USD 109mln of the co.’s stock, of which USD 21.7mln owned directly and USD 87.5mln indirectly, as held by his wife. (Newswires)

Ford (F) – Two senators have asked the US Transportation Department to explain why a “do not drive” directive issued by Ford, is limited to 2900 older pickup trucks, and are raising the question whether other vehicles are potentially at risk from defective airbags. (Newswires)

Kroger (KR) / General Mills (GIS) / Bed bath and Beyond (BBBY) / Overstock (OSTK) – General Mills and Bed Bath and Beyond are both weighing investments in Boxed.com, according to sources. Sources also added Boxed.com is in advanced talks to be sold to Kroger (KR). Kroger may also be eyeing a deal for Overstock.com (OSTK). (Newswires)

Lincoln National (LNC) – The financial group has entered into an agreement to acquire Liberty Life Assurance Company of Boston. The agreement requires Lincoln Financial group to pay Liberty Mutual roughly USD 3.3bln. (Newswires)

Lowe’s (LOW) – The retailer is adding 3 new members to its board following pressure from DE Shaw. (Newswires)

MetLife Inc (MET) – The US government and the co. announced on Thursday to mutually dismiss an earlier request from the Financial Stability Oversight Council (FSOC) regarding stricter oversight over the insurance giant as a vital part of the financial system. (Newswires)

Prudential Financial (PRU) – The co. has been added to focus list at Citi and Voya Financial (VOYA) have been removed. (Newswires)

Time Warner (TWX) – The co.’s digital networks division is planning to launch its movie streaming video on demand service, Film Struck internationally. (Variety)

United Continental (UAL) – The airline is to offer premium economy on its international flights. (CNBC)

 

NASDAQ 100

Activision Blizzard (ATVI) – The entertainment co. recommends shareholders to reject the mini-tender offer from TRC capital. (Newswires)

Alphabet Inc (GOOGL) – The tech giant agreed to licensing a patent deal with the Chinese social media and gaming platform, Tencent Holdings, to enter the Chinese market; financial terms not disclosed. Separately, its price target has been raised to USD 1280 at Key Bank. (Newswires)

Amazon (AMZN) – As Toronto was on the retailer’s shortlist for a new headquarters location, it may raise tensions with US President Trump. (Newswires)

Amgen (AMGN) / Allergan (AGN) – The pharmaceutical companies announced the European Commission has approved marketing authorisation for Mvasi, a treatment for certain cancers. (Newswires)

Facebook (FB) / Netflix (NFLX) – KeyBank have raised both co. price targets to USD 270. (Newswires)

Qualcomm (QCOM) / NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) – Elliott Advisors says Qualcomm can value NXP for higher than USD 135/shr. Further, Elliott Advisors have boosted their stake in the NXP and are now the largest shareholder. (Newswires)

Texas Instruments (TXN) – The co. names Brian Crutcher as next CEO, effective June 1st. (Newswires)

 

OTHER NEWS

Acorda (ACOR) – The therapeutics co. is receiving bids from Biogen (BIIB) and Belgiums UCB, the talks are ongoing. (Newswires)

Aptiv (APTV) – The co. is being mentioned positively on FT Alphaville, chatter about bidding interest from Continental (CON GY). (FT)

Blackstone (BX) – The co. hires Joe Zidle to succeed Byron Wilden as firm’s investment strategist. (Newswires)

Broadsoft (BSFT) – The global communication software co. announced it received notice from US DoJ and FTC granting early termination of waiting period. (Newswires)

Genesee & Wyoming (GWR) – The railroad holding co. reports December traffic down 255,199 carloads, a 5.7% decline. (Newswires)

NetEase (NTES) – Goldman Sachs have raised co. price target to USD 432 from 340. (Newswires)

Snap (SNAP) – The media co.’s metrics are being questioned by Muddy Waters, in an article titled ‘The big con: How Tech companies made a killing by fudging their numbers’, (Newswires)

Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSM) – The co. forecasts revenue growth of 10-15% in 2018. (DigiTimes)

Scotiabank FX Daily: Shutdown Risk Drives Wedge Between FX & Broader Tone
content:
· USD mixed as distribution of G10 returns hints to risk aversion.
· CAD quiet, range bound into mfg sales; data-dependence elevated post BoC.
· EUR consolidating near highs; German political risk elevated into weekend vote.
· GBP retreats from fresh post-Brexit high on disappointing retail sales.
· JPY outperforming on sentiment, U.S. shutdown fears; BoJ risk next week.
· AUD a notable performer in context of broader tone.
· MXN consolidating impressive 7% rally from late December; NAFTA risk looms.

subject: China FX trading platform says counter cyclical factor is becoming neutral in the midpoint fixing mechanism
Barclays on the UK retail sales release
content: The Black Friday bounce of November was unwound in December, bringing retail sales back in line with the weakening trend that has been in place since the end of 2016. Total retail sales volumes rose at the weakest 3m/3m pace in six months despite covering the sales and festive season. Nonstore retail sales volumes, including online sales, were the weakest monthly and quarterly growth figures in a year. Today’s release remains in line with our macro forecasts and we continue to expect household consumption to drift lower (down towards 0.7% y/y later this year).

DAILY US OPENING NEWS: Stop gap bill to fund government through to mid-Feb was passed by the House, however faces dim chances of passing a Senate vote.
content:
19th January 2018

  • Stop gap bill to fund government through to mid-Feb was passed by the House, however faces dim chances of passing a Senate vote.
  • GBP back towards 1.39 following soft retail sales which had been distort by Black Friday sales in Novembers reading.
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US U. of Michigan Sentiment data and comments from Fed’s Quarles, Bostic and Williams.
     

ASIA

Asia equity markets mostly traded with cautious gains after a subdued performance on Wall St and with focus on whether Congress can avert a government shutdown. ASX 200 (-0.2%) was weighed by continued weakness in commodity-related stocks as well as a lacklustre financial sector, while Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) saw initial upside pared as participants awaited developments in Washington where the stop gap bill to fund government through to February 16th was passed by the House, but faces less certainty at the Senate. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.2%) somewhat took a breather from its recent ascent to all-time highs and Shanghai Comp. (+0.4%) was positive after yesterday’s GDP numbers and firm liquidity efforts by the PBoC. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally lower as Japanese yields increased in tandem with global peers including the US 10yr yield which rose above 2.63% and its highest since 2016.

PBoC injected CNY 130bln via 7-day reverse repos, CNY 90bln via 14-day reverse repos and CNY 10bln via 63-day reverse repos for a weekly net injection of CNY 590bln vs. last week's CNY 40bln net injection. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.4169 (Prev. 6.4401)

Japanese Government upgrades overall economic assessment in January which marks the first upgrade in 7-months. (Newswires)

BoJ is said to be optimistic in achieving their 2% inflation target withing two years but are cautious on the next move. People close to the BoJ say the market overreacted to the change in Rinban operations, which they say wasn’t meant to signal any broader policy shift. As a guide, this is relatively the same as recent source reports from the BoJ.

 

EU/UK/US

Fed's Mester (Voter, Hawk) reiterated further US rate hikes are appropriate in 2018 and 2019, while she added that the pace of hikes should be similar to 2017. Furthermore, Mester also stated that she favours 3 to 4 rate hikes this year and next. (Newswires)

White House is said to consider Fed's Williams for Fed Vice Chair role, according to press reports. (Newswires)

US House voted 230-197 in favour of the government spending bill to fund government through to February 16th, which then sent the bill to the Senate which passed the procedural motion to begin debate on stopgap bill but delayed the actual vote on the bill till Friday. (Newswires)

Fed is said to be working on plans to relax bank leverage ratio which could free up billions in bank capital. (Newswires)

 

EQUITIES

Equity markets are higher across the board, appearing to shrug off concerns over the potential government shutdown. The Dax is outperforming, led by ThyssenKrupp after they confirmed their targets and BASF who continue to rally after their positive trading update late yesterday. The FTSE underperforms slightly with a number of smaller companies issuing profit warnings, including: Carpetright, Dignity and Bonmarche whose shares all plummeted between 20% and 50%. Although none of these companies are in the FTSE 100, the knock on effect is clear to see with Kingfisher, a competitor to Carpetright, propping up the index. US equity futures pushed higher after reports that the Fed is said to be working on plans to relax bank leverage ratio which could free up billions in bank capital.

 

FX

The USD remained on the back foot in European trade as the threat of a government shutdown in the US becomes a reality ahead of the Senate vote. 60 votes in the Senate are needed to fund the government but it appears that the Republicans don’t even have the full support of everyone in their own party so getting an additional 10-15 from the Democrats seems unlikely. The JPY remained strong as sources in the WSJ said that the BoJ is optimistic of reaching its 2% inflation target within two years. UK retail sales disappointed, falling 1.5% M/M vs. expectations of a smaller 0.6% decline. Nevertheless, despite a brief dip in GBP on the back of the figures, GBP/USD reversed course as the ONS stated that shoppers are just moving their shopping earlier (NB: November data was much better than expected).


FIXED INCOME

UK bonds and STIR futures were already on the rebound ahead of the UK data, but built on their recovery gains on the big miss, albeit briefly. Gilts topped out at 123.78 (+16 ticks vs -21 ticks at the low), while the 3 month Short Sterling strip traded 1-2 ticks higher before slipping back to stand flat to 1 tick above par. So, pretty much the knee-jerk anticipated as the already erratic retail sales series was further clouded by seasonal factors and promotions. Elsewhere, Bunds are underperforming despite a decent bounce off the 160.31 low to 160.56 (-2 ticks vs -27 ticks at worst), with chart support respected again, while Eurozone peripherals are firmer, led by Spanish Bonos on upgrade speculation. US Treasuries have pared some losses with the 10 year future near the top of its 112.09-13+ overnight range and yield easing back to 2.63% after probing just above.

 

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent and crude futures trade lower with markets keeping a close eye on US production after the DoE inventory data on Thursday and following monthly oil market reports from OPEC and the IEA. The DoE data showed US production rebounded over 2% in the latest week to 9.75mln bpd, while the IEA today said that US production could soon top 10mln bpd, and overtake Saudi Arabia and Russia. Precious metals are benefitting from the weak USD and as markets fear a potential US federal government shut down.

IEA says global oil supply in December fell by 405k bpd to 97.7mln bpd due to lower North Sea and Venezuelan output.
- Maintains 2018 global oil demand forecast at 1.3mln bpd, down from 2017 growth of 1.6mln bpd.
- US crude supply is set to push past 10mln bpd, overtaking Saudi Arabia and rivalling Russia

content:

  • Frothy price action could continue but B&B indicator now up to 7.4
  • Clear and unambiguous New Year positioning for higher inflation

subject: Thyssenkrupp (TKA GY) says Q1 income will be in line with our guidance, confirms full year targets
FX Morning Colour: Dollar still stuck between rock and hard place
content:
USD

The Greenback is a broad loser again with the DXY languishing below 90.500 and only just above recent 3 year lows as its poor start to 2018 continues. Little or no sign of any positive impetus from rising US Treasury yields, as the prospect of another Government shutdown or last minute Senate reprieve looms. The PBoC has fixed the Usd/Cny mid-point lower again, while Usd/Jpy has seen bids filled at 110.60 support to test buying interest just ahead of 110.50 on the back of latest reports that the BoJ is more confident about achieving its inflation target within 2 years. 110.15 is the next downside target before more buy orders between 110.00-15. Aud/Usd has extended gains above 0.8000 and Nzd/Usd has recaptured 0.7300 despite a marked slowdown in NZ manufacturing PMI overnight. Eur/Usd has bounced firmly off 1.2200-50 and looking to re-test 1.2300, Cable is almost back up to post-Brexit vote peaks around 1.3940 and Usd/Chf is heading towards 0.9500 having breached Wednesday’s 0.9573 base. Usd/Cad is bang on the 1.2400 handle and 1.2350-55 forms the next downside objective.

UK DEBT AND STIR FUTURES: Mixed fortunes ahead of retail sales data
content: Some domestic data (at last) to digest and perhaps provide independent direction, but given the erratic nature of retail sales and added uncertainty surrounding Black Friday the latest official release may only prompt a knee-jerk or transitory response. For now, the Short Sterling strip is tentatively firmer, but external leads for Gilts ahead of Friday’s Liffe open are negative and indicate a gap down from the previous 123.62 settlement price through 123.50. In the cash markets, 10 year yields are very much in focus and the UK version is inching up towards 1.35%.

subject: Bunds: back under pressure and eyeing 160.30 support again
content: Another downturn in US Treasuries and a further decline in 10 year note futures below tech support has sparked some early downside pressure on Eurex where the German benchmark trades lower between 160.37-45 parameters vs Thursday’s 160.58 close. Key support at 160.30 held in yesterday, but remains a near term target for bears ahead of January’s 160.11 base as the 10 year yield continues to nudge up against the 0.6% level. Comments from ECB’s Coeure on Thursday underlined a more upbeat assessment of the economy, which is now deemed to be out of recovery and into growth mode, but still unlikely to materially alter the tone of forward policy guidance at next week’s meeting, despite hawks calling for a fixed QE end date. However, as US 10 year cash rates look to edge higher from 2.63% amidst 3-4 rate hike leanings this year and in 2019 from Fed’s Mester, bonds are likely to remain on the back foot.

subject: Additional European Equity stories post the release of the Daily European Equity Opening News
content:
Zodiac Aerospace (ZC FP) – Co. significantly improved its operating performance in 2017, according to Airbus (AIR FP) programmes head. (Newswires)

Airbus (AIR FP) – Co. says has significantly reorganised A380 production to reduce costs. (Newswires)

Esure (ESUR LN) – Co. achieved 2017 gross written premiums of GBP 820mln, up 25% Y/Y. Profit before tax up over 30% to GBP 95mln-98mln. CEO Vann is to step down with immediate effect. (Newswires)

British Land (BLND LN) – Co. has announced Simon Carter has been appointed CFO. (Newswires)

SEB (SEBA SS) – Co. announces changes to accounting principles, impairment and other items affecting comparability. Co. says application leads to an overall reduction in group shareholders equity of SEK 6bln. Co. says other items affecting comparability in Q4 results will amount to SEK -1.9bln before tax and SEK -1.7bln after tax. (Newswires) â€‹

Fevertree (FEVR LN) - Rumours in in the market suggest the company is a takeover target for Unilever, although they will have to pay at least GBP 28/share for the company. (Telegraph) 

AstraZeneca (AZN LN) – Co. receives approval in Japan for FASENRA. (Newswires)

Vinci (DG FP) – French Finance Minister says is confident that will find a compensation agreement with the company over its scrapped airport. (Newswires)

Kuka (KU2 GY) - Co. lowers 2017 guidance for Ebit-margin to approximately 4.3%, while guidance for sales revenues will be raised to approximately EUR 3.45bln for FY. (Newswires)

UNIPER (UN01 GY) DOWNGRADED TO SELL FROM HOLD AT INVESTEC

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS: Remy Cointreau (RCO FP) â€“ Q3 sales growth slowed to 3.2% on a LFL basis to EUR 317.7mln
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

19th January 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia equity markets mostly traded with mixed after a subdued performance on Wall St and with focus on whether US Congress can avert a government shutdown. ASX 200 (-0.2%) was weighed by continued weakness in commodity-related stocks as well as a lacklustre financial sector, while Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) saw initial upside pared as participants awaited developments in Washington where the stop gap bill to fund government through to February 16th was passed by the House, but faces less certainty in the Senate. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.2%) somewhat took a breather from its recent ascent to all-time highs and Shanghai Comp. (+0.4%) was positive after yesterday’s GDP numbers and firm liquidity efforts by the PBoC.

FTSE

AstraZeneca (AZN LN) – Co.’s research productivity increased from 4% in 2005-2010 to 19% in 2012-2016. (Newswires)

HSBC Holdings (HSBA LN) – The bank is said to pay USD 101.5mln to end US currency probe. (Newswires)

UK Banks – Five UK banks are facing heavy losses from Carillion after the company went into liquidation earlier this week, according to sources. (Newswires) Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS LN) has announced a GBP 75mln fund for businesses in Carillion’s supply chain while HSBC (HSBA LN) has announced a GBP 100mln emergency fund for small Carillion suppliers, (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

INTERCONTINENTAL HOTELS (IHG LN) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM NEUTRAL AT GOLDMAN SACHS

BANK OF IRELAND (BIRG LN) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM SELL AT SOCGEN

KERRY GROUP (KYGA LN) DOWNGRADED TO HOLD FROM BUY AT LIBERUM

DAX

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – The bank’s CEO says, “we have always maintained that the reorganisation would take longer than one or two years” and notes the political vacuum in Germany is a major risk for the economy. (Newswires)  

ThyssenKrupp (TKA GY) – Co. is to refine its corporate strategy soon in the wake of growing investor criticism. (Handelsblatt)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Software AG (SOW GY) – Co. is to take a hit in the mid-single digit million euros range for 2017 due to US tax reform. In 2018 and going forward group EPS is expected to increase 5-10%. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

COMMERZBANK (CBK GY) UPGRADED TO OVERWEIGHT FROM EQUAL WEIGHT AT MORGAN STANLEY 

CAC

BNP Paribas (BNP FP) – The co. is to buy Banco BPM depositary banking business for deal worth around EUR 200mln. (Newswires)

Remy Cointreau (RCO FP) – Q3 sales growth slowed to 3.2% on a LFL basis to EUR 317.7mln. Co. confirms goal for growth in current operating profit at constant FX rates and scope. (Newswires)

Schneider Electric (SU FP) – Co. said that hackers had exploited a flaw in its technology that halted operations at an undisclosed industrial facility. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

For French banks – ECB’s Villeroy said ready to trigger counter cyclical cushion if necessary. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

DANONE (BN FP) UPGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM OUTPERFORM AT CREDIT SUISSE

PERNOD RICARD (RI FP) DOWNGRADED TO SELL FROM HOLD AT LIBERUM

AIR FRANCE (AF FP) DOWNGRADED TO EQUAL WEIGHT FROM OVERWEIGHT AT MORGAN STANLEY

PAN-EUROPE

UniCredit (UCG IM) – The CEO has no comment on the rumours that he is leading candidate for Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) CEO, says he has a long-term commitment to UniCredit. (Newswires)

Atlantia (ATL IM)/Abertis (ABE SM)/Hochtief (HOT GY) – Atlantia is to raise its offer for Abertis as soon as Hochtief’s rival bid is approved by the Spanish regulator CNMV, according to sources. (Boersen-Zeitung)

Geox (GEO IM) – Co. is set to appoint Gucci manager Mascazzini as its new CEO. (Newswires)

Colonial (COL SM) – Co. is to invest around EUR 480mln in new real estate projects this year. (Newswires)

Pharma Mar (PHM SM) – Co.’s Corail phase 3 study with Zepsyre has not met its primary endpoint. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

FERROVIAL (FER SM) DOWNGRADED TO SELL FROM HOLD AT DEUTSCHE BANK

BANKIA (BKIA SM) DOWNGRADED TO HOLD FROM BUY AT DEUTSCHE BANK

SMI

Nestle (NESN SW) – The co. nominates three new independent directors to the board. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

GEBERIT (GEBN SW) UPGRADE TO BUY FROM HOLD AT SOCGEN

SCANDINAVIA

CARLSBERG (CARLB DC) DOWNGRADED TO HOLD FROM BUY AT LIBERUM

US

US stocks were mixed, trading negative in early trade after rising to new record highs this week, though the S&P 500 seemed to be clinging to the 2800 mark, while the Dow Jones was hovering around 26,000. In later trade, however, stock indices were content to look through warnings of a Government shutdown, and the S&P 500 was lifted to fresh highs, before falling again as it emerged that Democrat opposition in the Senate is likely to be a stumbling block, likely leading to a government shutdown. EQUITIES: S&P 500 0.16% at 2798, DJIA -0.36% at 26021, NDX +0.02% at 6811

Top performers: Tech +0.15%, Telecom +0.14%, Healthcare +0.03%

Bottom performers: Utilities -0.78%, Energy -0.78%, Industrials -0.5%

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Stop gap bill to fund government through to mid-Feb was passed by the House, however faces dim chances of passing a Senate vote.
content:
• Stop gap bill to fund government through to mid-Feb was passed by the House, however faces dim chances of passing a Senate vote.
  • Oil slips some 1% in Asian trade with Brent tripping through USD 69/bbl.
  • Looking ahead, highlights include UK Retail Sales, US U. of Michigan Sentiment data and comments from Fed’s Quarles, Bostic and Williams.

ASIA

Asia equity markets mostly traded with cautious gains after a subdued performance on Wall St and with focus on whether Congress can avert a government shutdown. ASX 200 (-0.2%) was weighed by continued weakness in commodity-related stocks as well as a lacklustre financial sector, while Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) saw initial upside pared as participants awaited developments in Washington where the stop gap bill to fund government through to February 16th was passed by the House, but faces less certainty at the Senate. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.2%) somewhat took a breather from its recent ascent to all-time highs and Shanghai Comp. (+0.4%) was positive after yesterday’s GDP numbers and firm liquidity efforts by the PBoC. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally lower as Japanese yields increased in tandem with global peers including the US 10yr yield which rose above 2.63% and its highest since 2016.

PBoC injected CNY 130bln via 7-day reverse repos, CNY 90bln via 14-day reverse repos and CNY 10bln via 63-day reverse repos for a weekly net injection of CNY 590bln vs. last week's CNY 40bln net injection. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.4169 (Prev. 6.4401)


UK/EU

French President Macron said if the UK wants access to the single market, it can choose between the Norway model or full-membership. (Newswires)
 

FX

In FX markets, price action was relatively quiet amid a lack of economic releases or key overnight speakers. Nonetheless, USD was subdued as all focus turned to US Congress where the House voted for the stop gap bill but passage at the Senate looks to be tougher. This underpinned GBP/USD back above 1.3900 and saw USD/JPY give up the 111.00 level. Elsewhere, antipodeans were mixed with AUD underpinned alongside CNY strength and after a firmer reference rate by the PBoC, while a 5yr low New Zealand Business PMI kept NZD subdued.

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed with oil prices on the back foot as Brent tripped through stops as it slipped below USD 69/bbl and in which WTI briefly fell below USD 63/bbl amid no news catalysts, although some had noted that relatively increased volumes suggested position unwinding. Elsewhere, gold prices were underpinned amid weakness in the greenback, although is still on course to snap a 5-week win streak, while copper was slightly higher alongside the cautious gains in the regional risk assets.


US

The US Treasury curve bear steepened after China reported solid growth data for Q4, and the steepness was maintained as we entered North American trade. Additionally, news that Apple was set to repatriate a large amount of offshore capital helped keep the risk mood firm. Benchmark 10-year yields rose above 2.62% during US trade.

Fed's Mester (Voter, Hawk) reiterated further US rate hikes are appropriate in 2018 and 2019, while she added that the pace of hikes should be similar to 2017. Furthermore, Mester also stated that she favours 3 to 4 rate hikes this year and next. (Newswires)

White House is said to consider Fed's Williams for Fed Vice Chair role, according to press reports. (Newswires)

US House voted 230-197 in favour of the government spending bill to fund government through to February 16th, which then sent the bill to the Senate which passed the procedural motion to begin debate on stopgap bill but delayed the actual vote on the bill till Friday. (Newswires)

Twitter sources reported that US Republican Senator Flake indicated he would not vote for the House-passed Continuing Resolution and prefers Senate Minority Leader Schumer’s pitch for a short-term patch, while there were also reports prior to the House vote that US Republican Sen. Rand Paul stated he will not vote for stop gap bill and that Senate Democrats stated they had the votes to block the government funding bill. (Twitter/Newswires/Politico)

Some lawmakers expect to remain in Washington over the weekend to resolve any government spending issues. (Fox News)

subject: Hoban and Elion are said to have submitted final bids for stake in Daewoo E&C (047040 KS)
ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asia traded with cautious gains as focus centred on US congress where the House voted for the stop gap bill, but Senate passage looks tougher
content: Asia equity markets mostly traded with cautious gains after a subdued performance on Wall St and with focus on whether Congress can avert a government shutdown. ASX 200 (-0.2%) was weighed by continued weakness in commodity-related stocks as well as a lacklustre financial sector, while Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) saw initial upside pared as participants awaited developments in Washington where the stop gap bill to fund government through to February 16th was passed by the House, but faces less certainty at the Senate. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.2%) somewhat took a breather from its recent ascent to all-time highs and Shanghai Comp. (+0.4%) was positive after yesterday’s GDP numbers and firm liquidity efforts by the PBoC. Finally, 10yr JGBs were marginally lower as Japanese yields increased in tandem with global peers including the US 10yr yield which rose above 2.6% and its highest since 2016.

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Cautious gains seen in Asia as government shutdown deadline looms again
content:
Asia equity markets trade with cautious gains after a subdued performance on Wall St and with focus on whether Congress can avert a government shutdown. ASX 200 (-0.1%) is subdued by continued weakness in commodity-related stocks as well as a lacklustre financial sector, while Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) is mildly positive with upside contained as participants await developments in Washington where the stopgap bill to fund government through to February 16th was passed by the House, but has less certainty at the Senate. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.1%) takes a breather from its recent ascent to all-time highs and Shanghai Comp. (+0.3%) is positive after yesterday’s GDP numbers and firm liquidity efforts by the PBoC which resulted to a weekly net injection of CNY 590bln.

In FX markets, price action is relatively quiet amid a lack of economic releases or key overnight speakers. Nonetheless, USD was range-bound in anticipation whether a shutdown will be averted, which has also resulted to indecision in USD/JPY as the pair is stuck near the 111.00 level for lack of a better catalyst. Elsewhere, antipodeans are mixed with AUD underpinned alongside CNY strength and after a firmer reference rate by the PBoC, while a 5yr low New Zealand Business PMI keeps NZD subdued.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are lower as Japanese yields increase in tandem with global peers including the US 10yr yield which rose above 2.6% and its highest since 2016.

PRE-MARKET TAIWAN AND SINGAPORE STOCK NEWS: TSMC (2330 TT) reported record net for last year
content:
TAIWAN

Mega International Commercial Bank (2806 TT)
- Co. greed to pay a USD 29mln fine to US regulators for compliance failures at three US branches. (Taipei Times)

TSMC (2330 TT)
- Co. Q4 net TWD 99.3bln vs. Exp. TWD 97.2bln and record net TWD 343.1bln for 2017. (Newswires)
- Co. reported quarterly revenue of TWD 277.57bln.
- Co. expects decline of high-end smartphone shipments this year, although sees it being offset by cryptocurrency mining business.

Other News

- Financial Supervisory Commission Chairman said that the commission would continue to streamline its regulatory efforts. (Taipei Times)
